questions.text: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Herpes-simplex virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpes simplex virus causes distinctive punched-out ulcers in the esophagus, particularly noted in immunocompromised patients, diagnosed by endoscopic appearance and confirmed via histopathological findings.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male is brought to OPD with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. On examination, a mass was observed on left posterior choanae as shown below. What is the management of the patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Surgical excision

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected JNA, especially with the classical presentation of recurrent nosebleeds in adolescent males, prompt referral for imaging and surgical consultation is critical. Surgical excision, following detailed imaging and possibly preoperative embolization, represents the best approach to manage this condition effectively.

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation?( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Super supraglottic swallow

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Competitive

  • ➤ In competitive inhibition, the Lineweaver-Burk plot shows lines that cross at the y-axis, indicating that Vmax remains unchanged while Km increases due to the competition between the inhibitor and the substrate for the enzyme's active site.

questions.text: What percentage of increase in FEV1 represents the minimum change required to demonstrate the reversibility of obstruction after administration of bronchodilators in bronchial asthma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) > 12%

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • To diagnose bronchial asthma, it is essential to demonstrate the reversibility of airway obstruction. This is typically assessed by measuring the increase in FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second) after the administration of a bronchodilator .
  • • reversibility of airway obstruction.
  • • increase in FEV1
  • • after the administration of a bronchodilator
  • • The criteria for significant reversibility in FEV1 are:
  • • An increase in FEV1 of more than 12% from the baseline. An absolute increase in FEV1 of more than 200 ml.
  • • An increase in FEV1 of more than 12% from the baseline.
  • • more than 12%
  • • An absolute increase in FEV1 of more than 200 ml.
  • • more than 200 ml.
  • • These criteria confirm that the obstruction is reversible, which is a hallmark of asthma.
  • • Note - Criterion is used for assessing peak flow rate (PFR) variability is > 20% .
  • • Note -
  • • > 20%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A minimum increase of more than 12% in FEV1 after bronchodilator administration is required to demonstrate the reversibility of airway obstruction in bronchial asthma.

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Electron microscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Test for mucociliary clearance is: Saccharin with or without color test in vivo - Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance. Radioisotope transport testing in vivo Measuring ciliary activity in vitro Nasal nitric oxide - Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results. The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.
  • ➤ Test for mucociliary clearance is: Saccharin with or without color test in vivo - Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance. Radioisotope transport testing in vivo Measuring ciliary activity in vitro Nasal nitric oxide - Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results. The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.
  • ➤ Saccharin with or without color test in vivo - Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance. Radioisotope transport testing in vivo Measuring ciliary activity in vitro Nasal nitric oxide - Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results. The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.
  • ➤ Saccharin with or without color test in vivo - Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance.
  • ➤ Radioisotope transport testing in vivo
  • ➤ Measuring ciliary activity in vitro
  • ➤ Nasal nitric oxide - Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value
  • ➤ Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction
  • ➤ Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results.
  • ➤ The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with motor traffic accident with BP 90/60mm Hg. On examination, he was stable with GCS 15/15. The pupil was reactive to light. Tenderness and bruising over the left lower chest wall with petechia were seen. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. eFAST

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The next step in the evaluation of a trauma patient with the given findings is the Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (eFAST). This non-invasive imaging technique is crucial for rapidly identifying free fluid and organ injuries in the abdomen, as well as potential pneumothorax or hemothorax, which are critical in trauma cases. eFAST is used to quickly assess both stable and unstable patients following blunt abdominal trauma, providing immediate information that can dictate further management steps.
  • • both stable and unstable patients
  • • Details:
  • • Details:
  • • eFAST Role: This ultrasound examination checks for free intraperitoneal or pericardial fluid and can evaluate the integrity of the pleural spaces.
  • • eFAST Role:
  • • Stability: Despite the patient's low blood pressure, he is neurologically intact (GCS 15/15) and responsive, which allows for an ultrasound examination before more invasive procedures are considered.
  • • Stability:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Exploratory laparotomy: Generally reserved for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability after eFAST or when eFAST is positive for intra-abdominal injury needing surgical intervention.
  • • Option A. Exploratory laparotomy:
  • • Option B. Intubation: Might be necessary if respiratory status worsens or if advanced airway management is required, but the patient’s current stable neurological status does not immediately warrant this.
  • • Option B. Intubation:
  • • Option D. CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT Scan): Used after eFAST if the patient remains hemodynamically stable and further detailed evaluation of internal injuries is necessary.
  • • Option D. CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT Scan):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: In which of the following conditions prolactin level is highest? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 24 hours after delivery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Among the given options, the prolactin level is highest 24 hours after delivery.
  • • This hormone is secreted by the mother’s anterior pituitary gland, and its concentration in her blood rises steadily from the fifth week of pregnancy until birth of the baby, at which time it has risen to 10 to 20 times the normal nonpregnant level.
  • • 24 Hours After Delivery : Following childbirth, prolactin levels are significantly elevated to facilitate breastfeeding. These levels are particularly high immediately postpartum as the body prepares to produce milk to feed the newborn. This is the period when prolactin levels are typically at their highest among the given options.
  • • 24 Hours After Delivery : Following childbirth, prolactin levels are significantly elevated to facilitate breastfeeding. These levels are particularly high immediately postpartum as the body prepares to produce milk to feed the newborn. This is the period when prolactin levels are typically at their highest among the given options.
  • • 24 Hours After Delivery
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 24 hours after ovulation : Although hormonal changes related to the menstrual cycle do affect prolactin levels, these changes are moderate and do not typically reach the peak levels seen postpartum. The role of prolactin around ovulation is less pronounced compared to its surge after delivery, where it is critical for initiating and sustaining lactation.
  • • Option A. 24 hours after ovulation
  • • Option C. NREM Sleep : Prolactin levels naturally rise during sleep, especially during the deeper stages of NREM sleep, due to reduced dopamine activity, which normally inhibits prolactin secretion. Despite this increase, the levels achieved during sleep are usually not as high as those observed after childbirth, where prolactin plays a direct and significant role in breastfeeding.
  • • Option C. NREM Sleep
  • • Option D. After running for 1 hour : Physical activities and stress can lead to an increase in prolactin levels as part of the body's response to physiological stress or exertion. However, these increases are generally transient and significantly lower than the sustained high levels required for lactation post-delivery.
  • • Option D. After running for 1 hour

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Other factors which leads to high prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) in the body are:
  • ➤ Other factors which leads to high prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) in the body are:
  • ➤ During sleep, the hypothalamus releases dopamine, which inhibits the secretion of jectiveprolactin. As the night progresses and sleep deepens, dopamine levels decrease, leading to a decrease in the inhibition of prolactin release. Consequently, prolactin levels rise, reaching their peak in the early morning hours.
  • ➤ Prolactinoma: The most common cause of hyperprolactinemia is a noncancerous tumour of the pituitary gland called a prolactinoma.
  • ➤ Prolactinoma:
  • ➤ Medications: Certain medications can increase prolactin levels. These include antipsychotic (such as risperidone and haloperidol), antidepressants, anti-nausea drugs (such as metoclopramide), and some high blood pressure medications.
  • ➤ Medications:
  • ➤ Hypothyroidism: Underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) can disrupt the normal balance of hormones in the body, including prolactin regulation.
  • ➤ Hypothyroidism:
  • ➤ Chronic Kidney Disease: Kidney dysfunction or chronic kidney disease can lead to hyperprolactinemia. Impaired kidney function affects the clearance of prolactin from the blood, leading to elevated levels.
  • ➤ Chronic Kidney Disease:
  • ➤ Stress and Emotional Factors: Extreme stress, emotional trauma, or intense physical activity can temporarily raise prolactin levels.
  • ➤ Stress and Emotional Factors:
  • ➤ Pregnancy and Breastfeeding : During pregnancy, prolactin levels increase to prepare the breasts for milk production. After childbirth, prolactin levels remain elevated to stimulate and maintain breastfeeding.
  • ➤ Pregnancy and Breastfeeding

questions.text: A 60-year-old bedridden patient develops acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. A CT pulmonary angiography was done. Which screening test will be useful to determine the etiology of this patient's condition? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) D-dimer measurement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In a bedridden patient presenting with acute onset dyspnea and chest pain, one of the primary differential diagnoses is pulmonary embolism (PE). The patient has already undergone CT pulmonary angiography, which is a gold standard for diagnosing PE.
  • • However, for initial screening, D-dimer measurement is very useful:
  • • D-dimer measurement
  • • D-dimer: This test has a high negative predictive value and high sensitivity. It is a good screening test because if the D-dimer level is negative/ normal, it effectively rules out venous thromboembolism (VTE) such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and PE. Elevated D-dimer levels indicate that further diagnostic imaging, such as CT pulmonary angiography or compression ultrasound, is needed to confirm the presence of VTE, given its poor specificity.
  • • D-dimer: This test has a high negative predictive value and high sensitivity. It is a good screening test because if the D-dimer level is negative/ normal, it effectively rules out venous thromboembolism (VTE) such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and PE.
  • • D-dimer:
  • • Elevated D-dimer levels indicate that further diagnostic imaging, such as CT pulmonary angiography or compression ultrasound, is needed to confirm the presence of VTE, given its poor specificity.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. MR Angiogram: This is an imaging modality that can be used for vascular imaging but is not typically used as a screening test for PE.
  • • Option A. MR Angiogram:
  • • Option B. Echocardiography: This is useful for assessing heart function and diagnosing conditions like heart failure or valvular disease but is not a primary screening test for PE.
  • • Option B. Echocardiography:
  • • Option D. Coagulogram: This test assesses blood coagulation status but is not specifically used for screening for PE.
  • • Option D. Coagulogram:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives
  • ➤ D-dimer measurement is an effective screening test for ruling out pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of VTE.

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds to: ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Globin part of Hb

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 2,3 BPG has negative charge whereas beta chain of hemoglobin has large positive charges due to amino acids His and Lys. Together they form the salt bridges (see fig) which promote formation of taut conformation and helps in deoxygenation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with chest pain, dyspnea increasing on lying down and relieved on sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled and her lungs are clear. CXR given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Cardiac Tamponade

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiac tamponade presents with symptoms of chest pain and dyspnea that worsen when lying down and improve when sitting up, muffled heart sounds, clear lung fields, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette on CXR.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, when given with erythromycin, can cause QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Astemizole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Astemizole is a drug that, when taken with erythromycin, can lead to QT prolongation and the serious arrhythmia known as Torsades de pointes. This significant adverse effect led to the withdrawal of Astemizole from the market in many countries.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with lower back pain and fever. She has elevated amylase levels and has experienced similar episodes in the past as well. Which type of necrosis is likely to be present? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fat necrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fat necrosis is a hallmark of pancreatitis, particularly in the context of chronic alcohol use. It is caused by the action of pancreatic enzymes on surrounding fat tissue, leading to saponification and calcium deposition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. Which of the following should be avoided in management of the given condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Nil per oral to avoid pancreatic stimulation

options.label: C
options.text: Parentral nutrition preferred for 2-3 days over the nil per oral (NPO) approach

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Administration of 5% dextrose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of acute pancreatitis, avoid the administration of high glucose content solutions such as 5% dextrose, as they can exacerbate the condition, and instead focus on pain management, fluid resuscitation, and appropriate nutritional support.

questions.text: A patient had features of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability. He became bedridden and died due to respiratory failure. Brain biopsy is likely to show which of the following? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lewy bodies

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical features described (resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability) are characteristic of Parkinson's disease.
  • • In Parkinson's disease, the brain biopsy is likely to show Lewy bodies. Lewy bodies are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of aggregates of alpha-synuclein.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Hirano bodies: Seen in Alzheimer's disease and other conditions like Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
  • • Option B. Hirano bodies:
  • • Alzheimer's disease
  • • Option C. Guarnieri bodies: (Type B inclusion) Found in cells infected with poxvirus.
  • • Option C. Guarnieri bodies: (Type B inclusion)
  • • poxvirus.
  • • Option D. Negri bodies: Seen in the neurons of patients with rabies.
  • • Option D. Negri bodies:
  • • rabies.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Parkinson's disease, brain biopsies typically reveal Lewy bodies , which are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of alpha-synuclein.
  • ➤ Lewy bodies
  • ➤ intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies
  • ➤ alpha-synuclein.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Enveloped ss RNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Measles virus is characterized as an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus, notable for the unique clinical presentation of Koplik's spots, which precede the characteristic maculopapular rash. This distinguishing feature is essential for the clinical diagnosis of measles.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with left-sided hemiparesis. Damage to which part of the internal capsule leads to this presentation? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Posterior limb

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Damage to the posterior limb of the internal capsule can lead to contralateral hemiparesis due to the involvement of motor and sensory pathways.

questions.text: What dose of iron and folic acid should an anemic pregnant woman in her 2nd trimester be given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024

options.label: A
options.text: 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid twice a week

options.label: B
options.text: 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid once a week

options.label: C
options.text: 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily

options.label: D
options.text: 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid once a month

questions.correct_answer: C. 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, which aims to reduce the prevalence of anemia in India by 3 percentage points every year, the "6 by 6 by 6" strategy is used. This strategy targets 6 beneficiaries, includes 6 interventions, and involves 6 institutional mechanisms.
  • • One of the interventions is iron and folic acid supplementation.
  • • Anemic pregnant women in their second trimester should be given 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days, as per the guidelines of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program.
  • • For pregnant women, the recommended dose is 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days during pregnancy. This is provided in the form of red-colored tablets. The same dose is also given to lactating mothers for 180 days post-delivery.
  • • 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days
  • • If the woman does not respond to this dosage or is anemic, then other forms of iron supplementation, such as ferrous carboxy maltose and IV sucrose , may be considered.
  • • ferrous carboxy maltose and IV sucrose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the false statement regarding somnambulism? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: C
options.text: Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion.

options.label: D
options.text: There may be neurological conditions associated.

questions.correct_answer: B. Person will have full consciousness.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Person will have full consciousness.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sleepwalking (somnambulism) is an arousal disorder originating from deep, non-REM stage 4 sleep. Individuals who sleepwalk typically act without conscious awareness and have no memory of the episode upon awakening. The person who is having sleep walking is difficult to awake .
  • ➤ difficult to awake

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 555.

Ans. A) Line graph

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describe the effects of Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency? (AIIMS MAY 2021) Decrease in reduced glutathione Decreased NADPH Decreased lipid peroxidation Decreased RBC membrane damage

questions.text: A female patient presented with a lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Melanoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The lesion shown in the image exhibits characteristics commonly associated with melanoma, which include:
  • • Color variability: The lesion displays various shades of color, indicating the uneven distribution of melanin, which is a hallmark of melanoma. Asymmetry: If the lesion is divided into four quadrants, the halves do not match, suggesting asymmetry, another key feature of melanoma. Irregular borders: The borders of the lesion are not smooth or regular but rather irregular and jagged. Diameter: The lesion is likely greater than 6 millimeters in diameter. Evolution: There are changes in the lesion's appearance over time, including alterations in color, shape, and surface.
  • • Color variability: The lesion displays various shades of color, indicating the uneven distribution of melanin, which is a hallmark of melanoma.
  • • Color variability:
  • • Asymmetry: If the lesion is divided into four quadrants, the halves do not match, suggesting asymmetry, another key feature of melanoma.
  • • Asymmetry:
  • • Irregular borders: The borders of the lesion are not smooth or regular but rather irregular and jagged.
  • • Irregular borders:
  • • Diameter: The lesion is likely greater than 6 millimeters in diameter.
  • • Diameter:
  • • Evolution: There are changes in the lesion's appearance over time, including alterations in color, shape, and surface.
  • • Evolution:
  • • These features correspond to the "ABCDE" criteria used to identify potential melanomas:
  • • A symmetry B order irregularity C olor variation D iameter greater than 6 mm E volution over time
  • • A symmetry
  • • A
  • • B order irregularity
  • • B
  • • C olor variation
  • • C
  • • D iameter greater than 6 mm
  • • D
  • • E volution over time
  • • E
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma : Typically presents as a papulosquamous lesion rather than a pigmented one. It appears as a scaly, red, crusted nodule or plaque, often on sun-exposed areas.
  • • Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma
  • • Option C. Basal cell carcinoma : Usually manifests as a translucent nodule, surface telangiectasias and extensive local growth. Basal cell carcinoma lesions often have a rolled border and can ulcerate, forming what is known as a "rodent ulcer." They do not generally present with significant pigmentation or the described irregularities.
  • • Option C. Basal cell carcinoma
  • • Option D. Seborrhoeic keratosis : Appears as a benign, well-demarcated, pigmented lesion with a "stuck-on" appearance. It typically has a uniform color and texture and lacks the irregular borders, asymmetry, and color variation seen in melanoma.
  • • Option D. Seborrhoeic keratosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Melanoma should be suspected in lesions that show asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation, diameter greater than 6 mm, and evolution over time. The "ABCDE" criteria are essential in identifying potential melanomas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with Graves' disease with eye signs and enlarged thyroid is scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. What medication can be administered in the preoperative period to minimize intraoperative bleeding in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Potassium iodide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that results in an overactive thyroid gland, known as hyperthyroidism. In this condition, the immune system attacks the thyroid gland, causing it to produce more thyroid hormone than the body needs. As a result, the thyroid gland becomes hyperactive, leading to various symptoms associated with hyperthyroidism. Graves' disease is the most prevalent cause of hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presented with complaints of diarrhea and foul-smelling stool. His stool microscopy did not show any ova or eggs, but there was the presence of motile 200 μm larva. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Strongyloides stercoralis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Strongyloides stercoralis is diagnosed by the presence of motile larvae in stool, distinguishing it from other helminths that typically show eggs in stool samples.

questions.text: What are the stages of demographic cycle with same birth rate but variable death rate? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stage 1 + stage 2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The demographic transition model consists of five stages, each characterized by different levels of crude birth rates (CBR) and crude death rates (CDR). In stages 1 and 2, the birth rate remains high, while the death rate varies.
  • • Stage 1 (High Stationary): In this stage, both the CBR (green line) and CDR (red line) are very high, resulting in a relatively stable population size.
  • • Stage 1 (High Stationary):
  • • Stage 2 (Early Expanding): The CBR remains high, but the CDR starts declining due to improvements in medical facilities, more hospitals, and more doctors. This leads to population growth.
  • • Stage 2 (Early Expanding):
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • In stage 3 (Late Expanding ), the CBR starts declining for the first time due to the introduction of family planning programs, while the CDR continues to decrease. India is currently in this stage.
  • • stage 3 (Late Expanding
  • • In stage 4 (Low Stationary ), both the CBR and CDR are low, resulting in a stable population. This combination does not represent stages with the same birth rate but variable death rate.
  • • stage 4 (Low Stationary
  • • In stage 5 (Declining) , the CBR falls below the CDR, leading to population reduction. This combination does not represent stages with the same birth rate but variable death rate.
  • • stage 5 (Declining)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In stages 1 and 2 of the demographic transition model, the crude birth rate remains high, while the crude death rate is high in stage 1 but starts declining in stage 2, making these the stages with the same birth rate but variable death rate.

questions.text: Multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB shows resistance to which of the following drugs? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Isoniazid and rifampicin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, the two most important first-line anti-TB drugs.

questions.text: According to current recommended dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be of total energy intake: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) < 10%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be less than 10% of total energy intake.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of night blindness in pediatric age? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vitamin A deficiency

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Night blindness, also known as nyctalopia, is the inability to see well in low light or darkness. The most common cause of night blindness in the pediatric age group is vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is essential for the production of rhodopsin, a pigment in the retina that is crucial for vision in low-light conditions.
  • • vitamin A deficiency.
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Vitamin A deficiency : Leads to inadequate production of rhodopsin, resulting in night blindness. Common causes of vitamin A deficiency : Poor dietary intake, malabsorption disorders, or increased requirements during periods of rapid growth.
  • • Vitamin A deficiency : Leads to inadequate production of rhodopsin, resulting in night blindness.
  • • Vitamin A deficiency
  • • Common causes of vitamin A deficiency : Poor dietary intake, malabsorption disorders, or increased requirements during periods of rapid growth.
  • • Common causes of vitamin A deficiency
  • • Symptoms of Vitamin A Deficiency:
  • • Symptoms of Vitamin A Deficiency:
  • • Night blindness Xerophthalmia (dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea) Bitot's spots (foamy patches on the conjunctiva) Keratomalacia (softening of the cornea)
  • • Night blindness
  • • Xerophthalmia (dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea)
  • • Bitot's spots (foamy patches on the conjunctiva)
  • • Keratomalacia (softening of the cornea)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vitamin C deficiency : Causes scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums and perifollicular hemorrhages, but not night blindness.
  • • Option A. Vitamin C deficiency
  • • Option B. Congenital glaucoma : A rare condition that can affect vision but does not specifically cause night blindness.
  • • Option B. Congenital glaucoma
  • • Option D. Vitamin E deficiency : Can cause neurological problems and hemolytic anemia but is not typically associated with night blindness.
  • • Option D. Vitamin E deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin A deficiency is the most common cause of night blindness in the pediatric age group, emphasizing the importance of adequate intake of vitamin A for maintaining healthy vision, especially in low-light conditions.

questions.text: Methylisothiazolinone (MI) in cosmetics is used as? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Preservative

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It's important to understand that Methylisothiazolinone (MI) is used as a preservative in cosmetics to prevent microbial growth , distinguishing it from surfactants, humectants, and emulsifiers, which have different functional roles in product formulation.
  • ➤ Methylisothiazolinone (MI)
  • ➤ preservative
  • ➤ cosmetics
  • ➤ microbial growth
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 128, Page no 128.36
  • ➤ Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 128, Page no 128.36
  • ➤ Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4689087/
  • ➤ Online resources:
  • ➤ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4689087/

questions.text: A patient's relatives sent a message on social media to the consulting doctor, unaware about the other investigations. But he mentioned that urinary coproporphyrin is positive. What is the probable cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lead poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lead poisoning inhibits enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway, resulting in elevated urinary coproporphyrin levels, which is a key diagnostic indicator.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the CT image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) PUJO (Pelviureteric Junction Obstruction)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PUJO is characterized by massive dilation of the renal pelvis with thinning of the renal parenchyma due to obstruction at the pelviureteric junction. The pelvis is more dilated than the calyces, which is a hallmark finding on imaging.

questions.text: A patient presents in the OPD complaining of unable to evert the ankle. The following deformity is seen. Which of the following gait is present? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stepping gait

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The image shown in the question is the high stepping gait, seen in the common peroneal nerve injury. This gait is present due to foot drop or weakness of the foot dorsiflexors.
  • ➤ The image shown in the question is the high stepping gait, seen in the common peroneal nerve injury. This gait is present due to foot drop or weakness of the foot dorsiflexors.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with diarrhea and weight loss. On examination, the height and weight are lesser than expected. Laboratory investigations were positive for class II HLA-DQ2. Which of the following will you advise the child? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gluten-free diet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Children with celiac disease should follow a gluten-free diet to manage symptoms and prevent further intestinal damage.
